title: Ticket #3137: Reduce memory usage of libcondor_utils
description:
One of the things which really increases the shadow size is the non-shared portion of the data segment of libcondor_utils.so. It is currently 156KB in our releases.

This is due to:

  1. Attributes being defined as global symbols.
  2. Parameter table is copied in the non-shared segment. TJ reports that MSVC handles "static const" correctly for the parameter table; GCC definitely does not. Boo!
  3. Excessively large PLT.

1 can be addressed by switching to defines. 2 can be fixed by forcing the parameter table into the text segment. 3 can be helped by LTO (although, honestly, there are just too many compilation units!).

Patch is incoming - gets the data segment to 71KB.

Hunting around, there are still some large statically-allocated arrays of size PATH_MAX (4KB) which almost certainly wastes memory, as well as a few other small sins. See posting to condor-dev.
remarks:

2012-Jul-20 09:36:23 by bbockelm:
Hi Tim,

One thing I did not commit was statically linking the shadow to libcondor_utils. That saves another 100KB. I've not heard strong opinions for or against, but I'm personally for it.

Could you write such a patch? The one I have was a cop-out: I just created a new static library, condor_utils_static and linked the shadow to that. It works, but it ended up compiling condor_utils twice (felt like it was doubling the build time!).

Another thing - the original patch had some changes to build/cmake/CondorConfigure.cmake that I was playing with:

  1. Enabling -flto. Can you do an NMI run on a platform with a more recent GCC?
  2. Disabling exceptions. We could disable exceptions everywhere in libcondor_utils.
  3. Enabling -Os. This decreases code size at the cost of optimizations... but maybe right for Condor?

The latter two are commented out. Enabling LTO does seem to cause the compiler to find undefined references - some are in the schedd (easy fix), some are in CREAM (more difficult).

Brian

2012-Aug-01 15:32:03 by jfrey:
I don't see any problems with the changes, but I have a few questions:

Do your changes to the attribute names cause anything to move from non-shared memory to shared memory? Were the attribute names stored in non-shared memory before?

I did a quick check on a couple binaries. Before your changes, there was one occurence of the string "ATTR_JOB_UNIVERSE" per reference in the souce code (both in binaries and libraries). After your changes, there was one occurence of the string "JobUniverse" per source file that mentioned ATTR_JOB_UNIVERSE (both in binaries and libraries).

The primary benefit here seems to be shrinking the number of symbols that need to be resolved by libcondor_utils. I'm using rhel5. Do some of the copies of JobUniverse get coalesced with -flto?

Do your changes to the param table cause anything to move from the data segment to the text segment? Were the parameter names and string values previously in non-shard memory, along with the the param_info_t structs?

2012-Aug-03 10:32:52 by bbockelm:
Hi Jaime,

Yes - attribute names were in non-shared memory before. They are shared now.

Let's take "JobUniverse" as an example, a string of 11 characters. Previously, each reference to JobUniverse was an 8 byte pointer; it's now 11. Depending on the alignment, it's likely (but not guaranteed) many places will round this up to taking 16 bytes. Additionally, there was an entry in the library's and executable's hash map that contains the string "ATTR_JOB_UNIVERSE" (17 chars).

Each reference to the job universe requires a fairly large jump in memory to the other library, thrashing the cache.

So, for the 3 cases of ATTR_JOB_UNIVERSE in the shadow (don't forget to add the null byte), 2 * 18 + 3*8 = 60; 12+16+16 = 44 (looking at hexdump, in the condor_shadow, I see 3 cases of "JobUniverse", two of which are padded). In this case, repeating the string is a win. The bigger difference is that these strings were previously non-shared, and are now in the text section.

In the case of LTO, all the "JobUniverse" strings are coalesced into one, saving a few more bytes (16, I think); above, I quote the non-LTO case.

Brian
